posts.cooked:
In 2024, our swerve broke 1-3 times a competition. Fortunately, we had spares to swap in so that we could still play, but we would be out for a match if the module broke in between our systems check and our match.

We use MAXSwerve from REV, and it was our first year on swerve. Our team is considering switching modules, but first we are trying to figure out if it was a team problem and we weren’t taking care of them right, or if its a problem with MAXSwerve.

Anyone who could share what type of modules you have and how often they broke or give us any recommendations for keeping ours running would be greatly appreciated.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: We had max swerve break twice at both events we went to, 2 times were 550 related, 1 was the bevel gear locking up and 1 was a spark max burning Edit: we’ve also had 2 absolute encoders flat out fail and one melt

posts.name: Landon
posts.cooked: This was my team’s first year and our swerve worked really well once we had the coding fixed and the only breakdowns we had were from lose wires because someone put the wrong wire connectors on our robot, but we used sds mk4s with magnetic encoders. Also we only had to replace our swerve treads once and we went to three competitions and mix that in with preseason practice and season practice they held up great. We used two regular neos for drive and steering. And the absolute encoder that comes with it from Andy mark. Also make sure to put amp limits on the motor controllers! Also, my Theory for assembling them is there is never too much lock tite to hold it together.

posts.name: Aidan Ferrer
posts.cooked:
We had one issue in practice with the SDS modules, where a bolt fell out and locked up our modules + the bearing for the bevel shaft seized up. We think the problem was we didn’t use enough Loctite to secure the bolt and prevent thrust impact on the bearing, which was what we diagnosed to be the issue.

Other than that, we haven’t had any issues. Just regular usage and wear.

posts.name: Saber_8871
posts.cooked: Our SDS modules lost some screws but thats mostly because those were never properly loctited, other than that, we had one instance where the rotation seized up but this was due to a piece of metal getting lodged in the gearing.  Easily solved by removing the offending debris and putting a polycarb shield over the top plates.  Otherwise, no mechanical issues (the wheels even survived some falls from the chain, just some small chips taken out of them but still more than functional)

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: If you’re talking about mechanical failure, then that’s way too often. Our team has used Swerve X modules ( WCP ) for the last three seasons and never had a mechanical problem. We bashed up a couple of motors on our first set (we kept whacking them into the high bar during the climb until we added guards) and had an electrical problem in a module last season (our fault), but that’s pretty much it. We used them all pretty heavily too, especially the Rapid React set that took several crashes from the traverse bar without a hitch.

We run MAXSwerve and had minimal issues across 2 competitions this season and 1 offseason.

To keep them running reliably we had:

3d printed covers to make sure no debris got into the swerve module

hot glued all wires coming off the module to stop them from coming unplugged (I recommend doing this all over the robot, especially absolute encoders).

When you torque down the steering ultra planetary you have to be careful not to tighten too much or it will cause the module to bind when steering.

inspect the bevel gears every couple of matches to remove carpet debris that builds up.

We like to clean and regrease the module after each competition to keep everything running smoothly.

I hope this can help. If you have any questions about MAXswerve I would be happy to answer them

posts.name: Steven Carmain
posts.cooked:
We had problems last season with SDS chewing up the double gear and the one that connects to it to go down the side to drive.

We diagnosed it to a software issue, we allowed the driver sticks to go from 5m/s to 0 in one 20ms loop, so I assume the PID just saw immediate stop and slammed into reverse on the gears.

We put software acceleration limits or voltage ramp limits in, and it stopped the issues.

This season, our L2 system has lasted all season, 2 districts and 4 offseason events (88 matches), and still running great.  Just an occasional clean out of carpet/note dust and grease.

posts.name: Mark Wasserman
posts.cooked:
Haven’t had a mechanical failure for years.  We’ve had an encoder connector disconnect last World’s at the most inopertune time.   Matter of fact, encoder connection issues are the only thing i can think of in our 12 years of swerve.  This includes the ol’ optical encoders using Jaguar controllers.

Practice bot us a different story…

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Not fast swerve, but good swerve driven quickly

posts.custom_user_title: Not fast swerve, but good swerve driven quickly

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Honestly I am not sure there is much more mechanical complexity that can be taken out of the 2767 swerves.

That is not saying COTS is bad or anything, COTS just has to work for more and different robots, thus generally tighter packaging vs custom where you have more control.

Strategic:

Our team has used Swerve X modules

As far as our experience with OG swerve X: One bad countershaft bearing, one burned neo over 4 official competitions over 2 seasons (to my knowledge). We swapped ratios before worlds last year, so that gearing is newish.

(Lots of practice on a half field and some off seasons on these modues as well)

posts.name: Graham Howard
posts.cooked:
We had zero spare parts or drive motors for our MaxSwerve* last year and had no problems.

*Ignoring treads

posts.name: Brian Wagg
posts.cooked:
We’ve been using MAXSwerve the last 2 seasons, across 4 district events, 2 DCMP ’s and 1 offseason (soon to be a second offseason). Don’t believe we’ve had a single mechanical failure.

Only thing we’ve done for maintenance is a complete teardown and reassemblely at the start of build season of our modules. I will admit it takes some extra care to assemble the modules properly (not over tightening bolts is a big one), and be very attentive to anything that doesnt feel/seem quite right. If its not buttery smooth when turning the wheel or module, its time to inspect, likely disassemble, and reassemble.

The only “failures” we’ve had running these modules have been from poor crimps and improperly seated connectors (user error), and fortunately never in a match thanks to some very mindful students and their pre-match inspections (knock on wood…).

@Connour has typically overseen the assembly of our modules by students in the past, and the biggest words of wisdom I’ve heard him share repeatedly, is to read the manual thoroughly. Both before assembly, and during assembly.

posts.name: Jen Lawrie
posts.cooked: I don’t think we’ve seen a mechanical issue with our SDS modules. We’ve run swerve in 2023 (MK4) and 2024 (MK4i) across 11 events so far. We’ve had bolts come loose while practicing in our lab. No issues caused per se, just had to reassemble and add loctite. The main issues we’ve had than have taken out a module have been electrical. We’ve had two motors fail and twice had wires pull out of the PDH during a match.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked: Everything hasn’t been flawless, but we haven’t burn up any NEO550s and generally things have worked as intended.  The laundry list of things to check for, including making sure not to overtighten the Ultraplanetary stages and loctiting those bolts is true.  Also hot glue on all the connectors for the REV Throughbore encoders.  We’ve also had a module or two assembled wrong with the main pinion installed backwards, but if you are careful you should avoid that.  We’ve made sure to lubricate the gears and keep junk out with a cover.  The firmware update for the Flex controllers helped along with securing all the CAN connections for some issues.  Wheels have been lately are biggest inconvenience just trying to get a system that works for us, but overall it has been more pleasant than I even expected giving the challenges of swerve and how little maintenance was required on many pre-swerve drivetrains.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: Evan Kruger
posts.cooked: We run SDS Mk4i, and the only repairs we did were swapping out the large bearing on one module because it was making weird noises during practice, and having to swap out some motors the one time we managed to fry a drive Kraken.

Emphasis on the lubrication. We made our double gear teeth into triangles due to a lack of grease the past season.

Edit: I realize your reply was in regards to REV Swerve, not SDS which I was referring to.

reply_to_user.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: Ryan
posts.cooked: Once we switched to aluminum hubs and black tread, we have had 0 issues with MAXswerve over the past 2 seasons. This includes up to 4 in season events, 2 off season events and at least 3 showcase events with the general public driving the robot each year. Echoing the other comments about assembly, we triple check things when putting them together. 3d printed covers to block debris from 1 x 2 frame, superglued shaft key, trained student tightening 550 bolts, loctite everything you are supposed to, and regular gear inspection and maintenance are important.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
My kids actually practiced swapping motors (I am so sick of NEOs…) and swerve modules.  NASCAR pit style! At the Texas state champs we were the third pick and had a swerve issue going into the finals.  Our team mates were just gobsmacked to see our pit crew pull a module and swap in a module in under 10 minutes.

Before that they were thinking “OMG, we are doomed”…

I’d say we have to do something significant on a swerve (motor, loctite fail, or something that needs detailed diagnosis) maybe twice a competition? SDS MK4.  We’ve run L3 and L4.

Loctite, loctite, loctite

Oh, and make TWO crazy wheels.  Its an “in the queue” type swap and that dead module just costs you 25% of your tractive effort, rather than the match.  We loaned two crazy wheels to a team at the Robot Remix, and gave one to another team early in the season.  All three ended up boogered, but saved their bacon!  BTW, this is typical damage seen on all three.  No real clue how this happens on a totally flat field!  Maybe running the little rubber rollers at 5 million RPM causes enough drag to bend the Aluminum…  Wait, that’s actually 5,000 RPM at 17 feet per second.  OK, there’s your answer!  Hmmmm…  Teflon rollers???

posts.name: Henry Becker
posts.cooked: We have used the same set of SDS MK4i L2 for the past 2 seasons. We have used the same v1 Falcons for steering and v3 falcons for drive in '23 and Krakens in '24. We have had no problems both seasons and the have been through 4 regionals, 2 trips to worlds and an off season event. As long as the tread is cut right and installed correctly and everything is loctited and the gears are lubricated you should have no problems. We did have one issue with the v1 falcon cooling screw coming off into the inside of the motor and seizing the outrunner to the outer case, we fixed that by removing the plugs and taping over them.
